title: Galatians Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Galatians chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Galatians Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Galatians Chapter 2.

questions.question: How many years after did Paul go up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas and Titus?
questions.correctAnswer: Fourteen years
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:1 states that Paul went up again to Jerusalem fourteen years after.

questions.question: Who was with Paul when he went up to Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Barnabas and Titus
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:1 mentions that Paul went to Jerusalem with Barnabas and Titus.

questions.question: Why did Paul communicate the gospel privately to those of reputation in Jerusalem?
options: Lest he should run or had run in vain
So the Gentiles would not hear
questions.correctAnswer: Lest he should run or had run in vain
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:2 says Paul communicated privately so he would not run or had run in vain.

questions.question: Was Titus compelled to be circumcised?
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:3 clearly states that Titus, being a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised.

questions.question: What was the purpose of the false brethren who came in privily?
options: To spy out our liberty in Christ Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: To spy out our liberty in Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:4 explains that false brethren came in privily to spy out our liberty in Christ Jesus.

questions.question: How long did Paul and the others give place by subjection to the false brethren?
questions.correctAnswer: Not for an hour
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:5 states they did not give place by subjection even for an hour.

questions.question: What did the men of reputation add to Paul in the conference?
questions.correctAnswer: Nothing
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:6 says those who seemed to be somewhat in conference added nothing to Paul.

questions.question: Who was the gospel of the circumcision committed unto?
questions.correctAnswer: Peter
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:7 states the gospel of the circumcision was committed unto Peter.

questions.question: What did James, Cephas, and John give to Paul and Barnabas?
questions.correctAnswer: The right hands of fellowship
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:9 mentions they gave the right hands of fellowship to Paul and Barnabas.

questions.question: What did they ask Paul and Barnabas to remember?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:10 states they wanted Paul and Barnabas to remember the poor.

questions.question: True or False: Peter continued to eat with the Gentiles even after certain came from James.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:12 says Peter ate with Gentiles before certain came from James, but after that, he withdrew.

questions.question: Who was carried away with the dissimulation of the other Jews?
questions.correctAnswer: Barnabas
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:13 says Barnabas was also carried away with their dissimulation.

questions.question: What did Paul say to Peter when he saw his behavior was not according to the gospel?
options: I withstood him to the face
questions.correctAnswer: I withstood him to the face
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:11 says Paul withstood Peter to the face because he was to be blamed.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but ______ liveth in me.'
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:20 says 'Christ liveth in me' after 'I am crucified with Christ.'

questions.question: True or False: Paul teaches that a man is justified by the works of the law.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:16 teaches that man is not justified by works of the law but by faith in Jesus Christ.

medium.title: Galatians Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Galatians Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with legalism, thinking they must follow the law perfectly to be justified. Based on Galatians 2, what biblical truth would you share about justification?
options: A person is justified by faith in Jesus Christ, not by works of the law
Justification comes by strict adherence to the law
Only circumcision can justify a person
Justification is earned by good deeds and sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: A person is justified by faith in Jesus Christ, not by works of the law
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:16 clearly states that no one is justified by the works of the law but through faith in Jesus Christ. This is supported by verses 15, 20, and 21, which emphasize faith over law works.

questions.question: How does Galatians 2 teach us about maintaining integrity when faced with peer pressure in the church?
options: Stand firm and confront wrong actions openly
Follow the majority to avoid conflict
Ignore the situation and focus on personal faith
questions.correctAnswer: Stand firm and confront wrong actions openly
questions.explanation: In Galatians 2:11-14, Paul openly confronts Peter for withdrawing from eating with Gentiles, showing the importance of standing up for the truth and integrity in the church.

questions.question: A believer is concerned about fellowship with those who have different cultural backgrounds. According to Galatians 2, what principle should guide their attitude?
options: Fellowship should be based on faith, not cultural requirements
Only fellow believers of the same culture should be accepted
Cultural traditions must be strictly observed for fellowship
Avoid fellowship with those of different backgrounds
questions.correctAnswer: Fellowship should be based on faith, not cultural requirements
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:3-5 shows Titus, a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised, emphasizing unity in faith rather than cultural laws. This teaches us to value faith above cultural divisions.

questions.question: What does Galatians 2 teach about humility in leadership within the church?
options: Leaders should recognize that God shows no partiality and accept counsel
Leaders must always assert authority without question
Leadership is based on social status and reputation
Leaders should avoid fellowship with others to maintain power
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should recognize that God shows no partiality and accept counsel
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:6-9 shows Paul respected the leaders but also maintained his calling, with an understanding that God accepts no one's person, teaching humility and mutual respect in leadership.

questions.question: How does this chapter encourage generosity and care within the Christian community?
options: Remember the poor and be eager to help them
Focus only on personal spiritual growth
Avoid financial giving to maintain wealth
Give only when others demand it
questions.correctAnswer: Remember the poor and be eager to help them
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:10 highlights the request to remember the poor, which Paul was also eager to do, emphasizing practical generosity as a Christian virtue.

questions.question: A believer is confused about how faith and the law relate to Christian living. What guidance does Galatians 2 provide about living by faith?
options: Live by faith in the Son of God who loved and gave Himself for you
Live strictly by the law to prove righteousness
Faith is unnecessary if the law is followed
Rely only on human effort for spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Live by faith in the Son of God who loved and gave Himself for you
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:20 teaches that the Christian life is lived by faith in Jesus who loved us and gave Himself, showing reliance on faith rather than law obedience alone.

questions.question: How does Galatians 2 instruct believers to deal with hypocrisy within the church?
options: Address it openly to uphold the truth of the gospel
Ignore it to avoid offending others
Complain privately but take no action
questions.correctAnswer: Address it openly to uphold the truth of the gospel
questions.explanation: Paul confronted Peter openly in Galatians 2:11-14 because Peter’s behavior was not consistent with the gospel truth, showing the need to confront hypocrisy to maintain integrity.

questions.question: What does this passage teach about the importance of fellowship between Jewish and Gentile believers?
options: There should be mutual respect and fellowship without imposing cultural burdens
Gentiles must follow Jewish customs to be accepted
Jews and Gentiles should remain separate
Only Jewish believers are fully accepted
questions.correctAnswer: There should be mutual respect and fellowship without imposing cultural burdens
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:9 and 2:3-5 show that Jewish leaders gave Paul and Barnabas fellowship and recognized their ministry to Gentiles without forcing cultural customs like circumcision.

questions.question: True or False: According to Galatians 2, Paul agreed with Peter’s withdrawal from eating with Gentiles when Jewish believers arrived.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:11-12 shows Paul opposed Peter’s behavior because it was inconsistent and caused division, teaching that such withdrawal is not acceptable.

questions.question: True or False: Galatians 2 teaches that the grace of God is frustrated if righteousness is gained through the law.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:21 states that if righteousness comes by the law, then Christ died for nothing, indicating that relying on the law frustrates God's grace.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul says, 'I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but _____ liveth in me.'
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:20 teaches that the believer’s life is now lived by faith in Christ who lives within them.

questions.question: How does this chapter instruct believers to handle false teachers or those who bring in false doctrine?
options: Resist them quickly to protect the truth of the gospel
Accept their teachings to avoid conflict
Allow them to lead for a season
questions.correctAnswer: Resist them quickly to protect the truth of the gospel
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:4-5 shows Paul and companions gave no place to false brethren who sought to bring believers into bondage, emphasizing the need to resist false teaching.

questions.question: What principle about God’s impartiality is highlighted in Galatians 2?
options: God shows no partiality towards persons
God favors those of higher social status
questions.correctAnswer: God shows no partiality towards persons
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:6 states that God accepts no man's person, teaching that God is impartial in His acceptance of believers.

questions.question: According to Galatians 2, how should believers view the relationship between the gospel to the circumcision and the gospel to the uncircumcision?
options: Both gospels are distinct but equally important ministries
The gospel to the uncircumcision is superior
Only the gospel to the circumcision is valid
The gospel should be limited to one group
questions.correctAnswer: Both gospels are distinct but equally important ministries
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:7-8 explains that Paul was entrusted with the gospel to the Gentiles, as Peter was to the circumcision, showing both ministries are important and complementary.

questions.question: What does the chapter teach about living according to the truth of the gospel in community life?
options: We must walk uprightly without hypocrisy, reflecting the gospel truth
Compromise with cultural norms is acceptable
Avoid confronting others to keep peace
Separate from those who struggle with faith
questions.correctAnswer: We must walk uprightly without hypocrisy, reflecting the gospel truth
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:14 shows Paul rebuked the hypocrisy of Peter, emphasizing the need to live consistently with the gospel truth in community.

hard.title: Galatians Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Galatians Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Galatians 2:1-2, Paul mentions he went up to Jerusalem by revelation. What was the main reason for this visit?
options: To communicate the gospel he preached among the Gentiles
To seek financial support for his mission
To confront Peter about his behavior
To be circumcised according to the law
questions.correctAnswer: To communicate the gospel he preached among the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:2 states Paul went up by revelation to communicate the gospel he preached among the Gentiles to those of reputation in Jerusalem.

questions.question: According to Galatians 2:3, why was Titus not compelled to be circumcised despite being a Greek?
options: Because they recognized the freedom in Christ
Because he refused to follow Jewish customs
Because he was not allowed to enter Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Because they recognized the freedom in Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:3 shows Titus, a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised, highlighting the freedom believers have in Christ without the law’s burden.

questions.question: Who does Paul refer to as 'false brethren' in Galatians 2:4, and what was their intention?
options: Individuals who secretly came to spy out Christian liberty to bring believers into bondage
Roman officials intending to arrest Christians
Jewish leaders openly opposing the gospel
Gentile converts causing division in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Individuals who secretly came to spy out Christian liberty to bring believers into bondage
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:4 describes false brethren brought in privily to spy out the liberty believers have in Christ to bring them into legalistic bondage.

questions.question: How did Paul and the Jerusalem apostles view their respective missions as described in Galatians 2:7-9?
options: Paul was entrusted with the gospel to the Gentiles, and Peter to the circumcised Jews
Both Paul and Peter were sent exclusively to the Gentiles
Peter was to serve as Paul's assistant in all missions
They both pursued the same mission without distinction
questions.correctAnswer: Paul was entrusted with the gospel to the Gentiles, and Peter to the circumcised Jews
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:7-9 explains the distinct roles: Paul to the Gentiles and Peter to the Jews, showing early church mission strategy.

questions.question: What was the condition James, Cephas, and John placed on Paul and Barnabas as noted in Galatians 2:10?
questions.correctAnswer: To remember the poor
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:10 states the apostles asked Paul and Barnabas to remember the poor, emphasizing social responsibility in the early church.

questions.question: In Galatians 2:11-13, what behavior of Peter in Antioch did Paul oppose, and why?
options: Peter withdrew from eating with Gentiles fearing circumcision advocates, which was hypocritical
Peter refused to preach to Gentiles
Peter insisted on circumcision for all converts
Peter denied the resurrection of Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Peter withdrew from eating with Gentiles fearing circumcision advocates, which was hypocritical
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:11-13 narrates Paul opposing Peter for withdrawing from Gentile fellowship out of fear, which compromised gospel truth.

questions.question: What theological principle does Paul emphasize in Galatians 2:16 regarding justification?
options: Justification comes by faith in Jesus Christ, not by works of the law
Justification comes by strict adherence to the law
Justification is earned through good deeds
questions.correctAnswer: Justification comes by faith in Jesus Christ, not by works of the law
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:16 clearly teaches that no one is justified by works of the law but only through faith in Jesus Christ.

questions.question: According to Galatians 2:19-20, what does Paul mean by saying 'I am crucified with Christ'?
options: He considers his old self dead so that he now lives by faith in Christ
He was physically crucified alongside Jesus
He rejects all forms of Christian faith
He follows the Jewish law more strictly
questions.correctAnswer: He considers his old self dead so that he now lives by faith in Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:19-20 expresses Paul's spiritual union with Christ’s death and resurrection, living by faith in the Son of God.

questions.question: What does Paul warn against in Galatians 2:18 about rebuilding what was destroyed?
options: He warns that rebuilding the law after destroying it makes one a transgressor
He promotes returning to idol worship
questions.correctAnswer: He warns that rebuilding the law after destroying it makes one a transgressor
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:18 warns that if Paul rebuilds what he destroyed (the law’s old system), he becomes a transgressor of the gospel.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Galatians 2:6, Paul says, 'God accepteth no man's __________.'
questions.correctAnswer: person
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:6 states God accepts no man's person, meaning God shows no partiality based on human status.

questions.question: True or False: According to Galatians 2:21, Paul believes that if righteousness comes by the law, then Christ died in vain.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:21 clearly states that if righteousness could be gained through the law, Christ’s death would be meaningless.

questions.question: What kind of fellowship did James, Cephas, and John extend to Paul and Barnabas in Galatians 2:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The right hands of fellowship
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:9 describes how the pillars gave Paul and Barnabas the right hands of fellowship to affirm their mission to the Gentiles.

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul taking Titus with him to Jerusalem as mentioned in Galatians 2:1-3?
options: To demonstrate that Gentile believers need not be circumcised
To have him circumcised as proof of obedience
To introduce him as a new apostle
To have him represent the Jerusalem church
questions.correctAnswer: To demonstrate that Gentile believers need not be circumcised
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:3 shows Titus, a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised, illustrating the gospel’s freedom from the law’s requirements.

questions.question: According to Galatians 2:8, who empowered Paul for his ministry to the Gentiles?
options: The same God who empowered Peter for the apostleship to the circumcision
questions.correctAnswer: The same God who empowered Peter for the apostleship to the circumcision
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:8 states God who worked effectively in Peter toward the circumcision also empowered Paul toward the Gentiles.

questions.question: In Galatians 2:14, Paul confronts Peter publicly. What is the main accusation Paul makes against him?
options: Peter lives like a Gentile but compels Gentiles to follow Jewish customs
Peter denies the resurrection of Jesus
Peter refuses to eat with Jewish believers
questions.correctAnswer: Peter lives like a Gentile but compels Gentiles to follow Jewish customs
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:14 shows Paul rebuking Peter for hypocrisy—living like a Gentile but forcing Gentiles to live like Jews.

theological.title: Galatians Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Galatians Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Galatians 2:3, why was Titus not compelled to be circumcised?
questions.correctAnswer: Because he was a Greek
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:3 states that Titus, being a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised, emphasizing the freedom from the law for Gentile believers. This aligns with Acts 15:1-11 and Romans 2:28-29 where circumcision is shown as a covenant sign primarily for Jews, and believers in Christ are justified by faith, not law.

questions.question: What was the main concern Paul had about the 'false brethren' mentioned in Galatians 2:4?
options: That they would bring believers into bondage
That they would preach a different gospel
That they would be accepted by the apostles
That they would divide the church
questions.correctAnswer: That they would bring believers into bondage
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:4 warns about false brethren who came secretly to spy out the liberty in Christ to bring believers into bondage, referring to legalism and the bondage of the law as opposed to the freedom in Christ. This theme is echoed in Romans 8:2, Exodus 20:2-3, and John 8:34-36.

questions.question: In Galatians 2:7-8, Paul compares his ministry to that of Peter. What distinction does he make?
options: Paul to the Gentiles, Peter to the circumcision
Paul to the Jews, Peter to the Gentiles
Paul to the Pharisees, Peter to the Sadducees
Paul to the apostles, Peter to the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Paul to the Gentiles, Peter to the circumcision
questions.explanation: Paul explains that the gospel of the uncircumcision was entrusted to him, just as the gospel of the circumcision was to Peter, showing a divine order in ministry focus (Galatians 2:7-8). This distinction relates to Romans 11:13 and Acts 9:15 where Paul is appointed the apostle to the Gentiles.

questions.question: What did James, Cephas, and John do when they recognized the grace given to Paul, according to Galatians 2:9?
options: They gave Paul and Barnabas the right hands of fellowship
They rebuked Paul for preaching to the Gentiles
They asked Paul to circumcise Titus
They excluded Paul from the apostleship
questions.correctAnswer: They gave Paul and Barnabas the right hands of fellowship
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:9 shows that these leaders gave Paul and Barnabas the right hands of fellowship, symbolizing mutual recognition and approval of their respective ministries. This unity reflects principles found in Acts 15:22-29 and 1 Corinthians 9:1-2.

questions.question: What specific instruction did the apostles give to Paul and Barnabas regarding their mission, as stated in Galatians 2:10?
questions.correctAnswer: To remember the poor
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:10 records that Paul and Barnabas were asked to remember the poor, reflecting the early church’s concern for social justice and charity consistent with teachings in Proverbs 19:17, Isaiah 58:6-7, and James 2:14-17.

questions.question: Why did Paul oppose Peter openly in Antioch, according to Galatians 2:11?
options: Because Peter was to be blamed for hypocrisy
Because Peter refused to eat with Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Because Peter was to be blamed for hypocrisy
questions.explanation: Paul confronted Peter openly because Peter withdrew from eating with Gentiles when certain men came from James, which Paul saw as hypocritical and contradictory to the gospel's truth (Galatians 2:11-14). This addresses the principle of living consistently with the gospel as in Matthew 23:28 and James 1:22.

questions.question: According to Galatians 2:16, how is a person justified?
options: By faith in Jesus Christ, not by works of the law
By strict adherence to the law
questions.correctAnswer: By faith in Jesus Christ, not by works of the law
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:16 clearly states that justification comes through faith in Jesus Christ, not by the works of the law, affirming salvation by grace through faith as also taught in Romans 3:28, Ephesians 2:8-9, and Hebrews 11:6.

questions.question: What does Paul say about rebuilding what he destroyed in Galatians 2:18?
options: He would make himself a transgressor
He would be praised by the apostles
questions.correctAnswer: He would make himself a transgressor
questions.explanation: Paul explains in Galatians 2:18 that if he rebuilds the old system of law he destroyed, he becomes a transgressor, emphasizing the incompatibility of the law-based righteousness with gospel freedom. This is consistent with Romans 7:4-6 and 2 Corinthians 3:14-17.

questions.question: In Galatians 2:20, how does Paul describe his new life in Christ?
options: Crucified with Christ, yet Christ lives in me
Living by the law and works
questions.correctAnswer: Crucified with Christ, yet Christ lives in me
questions.explanation: Paul describes his identity as crucified with Christ and yet living because Christ lives in him, signifying union with Christ and new life by faith (Galatians 2:20). This theme is echoed in Romans 6:6-11, Colossians 3:3-4, and 2 Corinthians 5:17.

questions.question: What does Paul mean when he says in Galatians 2:19 that he is 'dead to the law'?
options: He is freed from the law to live for God
He no longer believes in God
questions.correctAnswer: He is freed from the law to live for God
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:19 explains that Paul is 'dead to the law' to live unto God, meaning the believer is released from the law's condemnation and now lives in the Spirit. This aligns with Romans 7:4-6 and 2 Corinthians 3:6.

questions.question: What does Paul assert about the works of the law and justification in Galatians 2:16?
options: No one is justified by the works of the law
Works of the law justify everyone
questions.correctAnswer: No one is justified by the works of the law
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:16 teaches that justification does not come through works of the law but through faith in Christ alone, consistent with Psalm 143:2, Isaiah 64:6, and Romans 3:20.

questions.question: According to Galatians 2:21, what would be the consequence if righteousness came by the law?
questions.correctAnswer: Christ died in vain
questions.explanation: Paul states in Galatians 2:21 that if righteousness came by the law, then Christ's death would be meaningless, highlighting the sufficiency and necessity of Christ's atoning sacrifice as in Hebrews 10:10 and Romans 5:8.

questions.question: What does Paul mean by saying 'God accepteth no man's person' in Galatians 2:6?
questions.correctAnswer: God shows no partiality
questions.explanation: Galatians 2:6 teaches that God does not show favoritism or partiality, affirming the impartiality of God as taught in Acts 10:34, Romans 2:11, Deuteronomy 10:17, and James 2:1-9.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'right hands of fellowship' mentioned in Galatians 2:9?
options: Mutual recognition and partnership in the gospel mission
A gesture of reconciliation after conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Mutual recognition and partnership in the gospel mission
questions.explanation: The 'right hands of fellowship' in Galatians 2:9 symbolize acceptance and partnership between Jewish and Gentile ministries, reflecting unity in the gospel mission as in Philippians 2:1-2 and 1 Corinthians 3:9.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the gospel he communicated to those of reputation in Galatians 2:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Privately and by revelation
questions.explanation: Paul states in Galatians 2:2 that he went up by revelation and communicated the gospel privately to those of reputation to avoid running in vain, emphasizing divine guidance and the importance of apostolic approval, consistent with Acts 9:15-16 and 1 Corinthians 15:8-10.
